channel.title: Comments on: I Want Assert.NotYetImplemented(); In .NET Test Frameworks

item.title: By: dotnetchris
item.dc:creator: dotnetchris
item.content:encoded:
I had some confusion on what exactly this meant, mainly from omitting the body specifically . What James was saying is that you should omit the entire assignment of an It assertion.

It should_have_name_foo;

Will show up as inconclusive on test runners.

item.title: By: Mark
item.dc:creator: Mark
item.content:encoded:
We just renamed out our FactAttribute to ThenAttribute and then subclassed that to EventuallyThenAttribute and added a message for all skipped tests.

[Then] public void the_something_happens(){}

[EventuallyThen] public void the_something_happens(){}

We’re dragging out feet on moving to MSpec as well.

item.title: By: Igor Brejc
item.dc:creator: Igor Brejc
item.description:
MbUnit has a number of different ways to achieve what you're looking for: see http://igorbrejc.net/development/continuous-integration/gallio-setting-test-outcome-anyway-you-like
and http://igorbrejc.net/development/continuous-integration/gallio-filter-attributes-for-test-methods
item.content:encoded:
MbUnit has a number of different ways to achieve what you’re looking for:
see http://igorbrejc.net/development/continuous-integration/gallio-setting-test-outcome-anyway-you-like

and http://igorbrejc.net/development/continuous-integration/gallio-filter-attributes-for-test-methods

item.title: By: derick.bailey
item.dc:creator: derick.bailey
item.description:
to the peeps that suggested Assert.Fail or throwing a NotImplementedException: you might want to read the blog post you are commenting on. :)
to everyone else: good suggestions! I'm not a fan of Ignore, honestly. i think the semantics between ignore and not yet implemented are significant, but that would at least work. i'll have to try out the Assert.Inconclusive, too. I was not aware of that assertion.
item.content:encoded:
to the peeps that suggested Assert.Fail or throwing a NotImplementedException: you might want to read the blog post you are commenting on. :)

to everyone else: good suggestions! I’m not a fan of Ignore, honestly. i think the semantics between ignore and not yet implemented are significant, but that would at least work. i’ll have to try out the Assert.Inconclusive, too. I was not aware of that assertion.

item.title: By: Matt
item.dc:creator: Matt
item.description: I second (third?) the call for the [Ignore] attribute. I committed a few "stub" tests just last night using that approach. :)
item.content:encoded: I second (third?) the call for the [Ignore] attribute. I committed a few “stub” tests just last night using that approach. :)

item.title: By: Dale
item.dc:creator: Dale
item.description: There is also the option of making the class or method under test throw a NotImplementedException and expect that exception in your test.
item.content:encoded: There is also the option of making the class or method under test throw a NotImplementedException and expect that exception in your test.

item.title: By: Dan
item.dc:creator: Dan
item.description: Could you create an Assert extention method that just called Assert.Ignore() ?
item.content:encoded: Could you create an Assert extention method that just called Assert.Ignore() ?

item.title: By: Harry Steinhilber
item.dc:creator: Harry Steinhilber
item.content:encoded:
MSpec already has this functionality. Simply declare but don’t assign the It delegate:

It should_do_something_I_will_care_about_soon;

This will generate a not implemented message very similar to how RSpec does it.

item.title: By: Alastair Smith
item.dc:creator: Alastair Smith
item.description:
Have you considered Assert.Inconclusive("Not yet implemented")? This should give you the nice yellow test result you seek, and should work with existing CI software too. It's definitely in NUnit 2.5, maybe 2.4 also.
IgnoreAttribute is also a good option, as other commenters have mentioned. There may be important semantic differences between Assert.Inconclusive() and IgnoreAttribute that I've missed.
item.content:encoded:
Have you considered Assert.Inconclusive(“Not yet implemented”)? This should give you the nice yellow test result you seek, and should work with existing CI software too. It’s definitely in NUnit 2.5, maybe 2.4 also.

IgnoreAttribute is also a good option, as other commenters have mentioned. There may be important semantic differences between Assert.Inconclusive() and IgnoreAttribute that I’ve missed.

item.title: By: Simon
item.dc:creator: Simon
item.description: If you wanted failing tests to remind you where you left off, you could use Assert.Fail("Not yet implemented") in the test body.
item.content:encoded: If you wanted failing tests to remind you where you left off, you could use Assert.Fail(“Not yet implemented”) in the test body.
